#Text=The three _primary_, solid cooking  s fats today are:
#Text=
#Text= [Illustration: _Butter Lard Crisco_]
#Text=
#Text= There are numbers of substitutes for these, such as butterine,
#Text= oleomargarine and "lard compounds."
#Text=The following pages contain a story of unusual interest to _you_.
#Text=For
#Text= you _eat_.
#Text=See Page 233
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= _The Story of Crisco_
#Text=
#Text= The culinary world is revising its entire cook book on account of the
#Text= advent of Crisco, a new and altogether different cooking fat.
#Text=Many wonder that any product could gain the favor of cooking experts
#Text= so quickly.
#Text=A few months after the first package was marketed,
#Text= practically every grocer of the better class in the United States was
#Text= supplying women with the new product.
#Text=This was largely because four classes of
#Text= people--housewives--chefs--doctors--dietitians--were glad to be shown
#Text= a product which at once would make for more _digestible_ foods, more
#Text= _economical_ foods, and better _tasting_ foods.
#Text=Cooking and History
#Text=
#Text= [Illustration]
#Text=
#Text= Cooking methods have undergone a marked change during the past few
#Text= years.
#Text=The nation  '  s food is becoming more and more wholesome as
#Text= a result of different discoveries, new sources of supply, and the
#Text= intelligent weighing of values.
#Text=Domestic Science is better understood
#Text=The Banishment of That "Lardy" Taste in Foods
#Text=
#Text= It was the earnest aim of the makers of Crisco to produce a
#Text= strictly _vegetable_ product without adding a hard, and consequently
#Text= indigestible animal fat.
#Text=There is today a pronounced partiality from
#Text= a health standpoint to a vegetable fat, and the lardy, greasy taste
#Text= of food resulting from the use of animal fat never has been in such
#Text= disfavor as during the past few years.
#Text=So Crisco is absolutely _all_ vegetable.
#Text=No stearine, animal
#Text= or vegetable, is added.
#Text=It possesses no taste nor odor save the
#Text= delightful and characteristic aroma which identifies Crisco, and is
#Text= suggestive of its purity.
#Text=Explanation of "Hidden" Food Flavors.
#Text=When the dainty shadings of taste are over-shadowed by a "lardy"
#Text= flavor, the _true_ taste of the food itself is lost.
#Text=We miss the
#Text= "hidden" or _natural_ taste of the food.
#Text=Crisco has a peculiar power
#Text=of bringing out the very best in food flavors.
#Text=Even the simplest foods
#Text= are allowed a delicacy of flavor.
#Text=[Illustration]
#Text=
#Text= Take ginger bread for example: The real _ginger_ taste is there.
#Text=The
#Text= _molasses_ and spice flavors are brought out.
#Text=[Illustration]
#Text=
#Text= Or just plain, every-day fried potatoes; many never knew what the real
#Text= _potato_ taste was before eating potatoes fried in Crisco.
#Text=Fried chicken has a newness of taste not known before.
#Text=New users of Crisco should try these simple foods first and later take
#Text= up the preparation of more elaborate dishes.
#Text=Butter, Ever Popular
#Text=
#Text= It is hard to imagine anything taking the place of butter upon the
#Text= dining table.
#Text=For seasoning in cooking, the use of butter ever will
#Text= be largely a matter of taste.
#Text=Some people have a partiality for the
#Text= "butter flavor," which after all is largely the salt mixed with the
#Text= fat.
#Text=Close your eyes and eat some fresh unsalted butter; note that it
#Text= is practically tasteless.
#Text=[Illustration]
#Text=
#Text= Crisco contains richer food elements than butter.
#Text=As Crisco is richer,
#Text= containing no moisture, one-fifth or one-fourth less can be used in
#Text= each recipe.
#Text=Crisco always is uniform because it is a manufactured fat where
#Text= quality and purity can be controlled.
#Text=It works perfectly into any
#Text= dough, making the crust or loaf even textured.
#Text=It keeps sweet and pure
#Text= indefinitely in the ordinary room temperature.
#Text=special precaution than that of keeping them in a cool place.
#Text=A very
#Text= effective method of preserving eggs for winter use is to rub a little
#Text= melted Crisco over each to close the pores, and then to pack the eggs
#Text= in bran, salt or sawdust, not allowing them to touch each other.
#Text=[Illustration]
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= _Methods of Cooking_
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= There are seven chief methods of cooking meat--roasting, boiling,
#Text= baking, stewing, frying, broiling and poaching.
#Text=The first three are most suitable for joints weighing four pounds
#Text= or more, but not satisfactory for smaller pieces which are liable to
#Text= become hard and flavorless by the drying up or loss of their juices.
#Text=Of the other three methods, stewing may be applied to fairly large and
#Text= solid pieces, but it is better for smaller thin ones, while frying and
#Text= broiling can be used only for steaks, chops, and similar cuts.
#Text=Braising and steaming are combinations and modifications of these
#Text= methods.
#Text=Roasting
#Text=
#Text= Roasting is one of the oldest methods of cooking on record, and still
#Text= remains the favorite form of cooking joints of meat or birds.
#Text=The
#Text= success of every method of cooking depends largely upon the correct
#Text= management of the fire.
#Text=In roasting, this is particularly the case,
#Text= as a clear, brisk and yet steady fire is needed.
#Text=To roast a joint it
#Text= should be placed before great heat for the first ten minutes and then
#Text= allowed to cook more slowly.
#Text=The great heat hardens the outside of the
#Text= meat and keeps in the juices.
#Text=If allowed to cook quickly all the time
#Text= the meat is likely to be tough.
#Text=The fire should be bright and clear.
#Text=The joint should be basted about every ten minutes, as this helps to
#Text=The dry or saute method of frying is less satisfactory, in that it
#Text= is difficult even after much practice to produce a uniformly colored
#Text= surface.
#Text=A small quantity of fat only is needed, and where the fat,
#Text= i.e., the heat, ends, a crack is formed in the outer coat, through
#Text= which flavor escapes and fat enters; the appearance also is rendered
#Text= unsightly.
#Text=Flat fish can be fried fairly well by this method, or,
#Text= indeed, almost any thin substance, as thin edges are not affected in
#Text= this way.
#Text=For pancakes and other articles of similar nature it is the
#Text= best method.
#Text=It rarely is possible to use the fat from the dry method
#Text= a second time, except for dishes of the same kind, as the fat always
#Text= is more or less flavored by the food cooked in it.
#Text=The most digestible
#Text= fat for frying and the best for results undoubtedly is Crisco.
#Text=Steaming
#Text=
#Text= Steaming is a process very similar to boiling, for it is cooking in
#Text= the heated vapor of water.
#Text=This practice as a means of cookery is
#Text= largely adopted in hotels, clubs, schools and hospitals, and other
#Text= large institutions; also frequently applied in ordinary home cookery
#Text=for particular articles of food requiring a very slow process of
#Text= cooking.
#Text=An ordinary kitchen steamer, with a close-fitting lid is
#Text= generally all that is required for simple household cookery on a small
#Text= scale.
#Text=The articles of food which are to be steamed are prepared in
#Text= exactly the same manner as for boiling.
#Text=Many puddings, some meats, and
#Text= some vegetables are considered better if cooked by steam, and inasmuch
#Text= as the process of cooking is a very slow one, there is no fear of
#Text= the food being destroyed by too fierce a heat, as the temperature in
#Text= steaming never reaches beyond 212° F.
#Text=Fish, meat and poultry cooked by
#Text= steam are as a rule tender, full of gravy and digestible.
#Text=By steaming,
#Text= watery vegetables are made drier; tough meats are softened and made
#Text= tender; while farinaceous mixtures and puddings develop a totally
#Text= different flavor when baked or fried.
#Text=Braising
#Text=
#Text= Braising is a combination of roasting and stewing small joints of
#Text= meat in a shallow stewpan.
#Text=It is a favorite method of cooking with
#Text= the French, and is supposed to bring out an unusually fine flavor and
#Text=aroma.
#Text=The pan in which a braise is to be made always should be lined
#Text= with slices of bacon, carrot, onions and herbs, upon which the meat is
#Text= placed.
#Text=It usually is moistened with stock or stock and wine.
#Text=The
#Text= more delicate meats, such as sweetbreads, fillets, fowls and turkeys
#Text= sometimes are covered with buttered paper; this is done to prevent
#Text= the heat from the top of the pan scorching or imparting too much of a
#Text= roast flavor to the meats which are to be braised.
#Text=Occasional basting
#Text= during the process of this method of cooking is essential.
#Text=When done,
#Text= the meat is taken up, the fat removed from the vegetables and gravy,
#Text= which latter is then reduced, strained and blended with some kind of
#Text= gravy or thin sauce.
#Text=Poaching and Marinating
#Text=
#Text= Poaching is the name usually given to the process of cooking an
#Text= article by placing it for a few minutes in boiling water.
#Text=Marinating
#Text= or pickling is a process with a formidable name with a simple meaning.
#Text=To marinate simply is to soak meat in a mixture for some hours, or
#Text= even days, with the idea of improving its flavor of softening its
#Text=fibres and making it tender.
#Text=Vinegar, oil, pepper and salt are mixed
#Text= together and the meat packed in the mixture; sometimes a sliced onion
#Text= and herbs are added.
#Text=The meat, of course, should be wiped first, but
#Text= not washed.
#Text=Cooking in Earthenware
#Text=
#Text= Stone or earthenware cooking appliances are used to very great
#Text= advantage for various forms of preparing food.
#Text=For the homely
#Text= _pot-au-feu_ the French housewife has used fireproof earthenware
#Text= dishes for generations, and does so today.
#Text=But besides soups, various
#Text= savory dishes, and all sorts of stews are cooked in stoneware pots.
#Text=Indeed, so much has this form of cookery come into fashion that many
#Text= dishes are sent to table in the pots in which they are cooked.
#Text=Cooking
#Text= in stoneware has no equal where slow cooking is aimed at, and there
#Text= are many dishes which one would do well to refrain from attempting
#Text= unless cooked in this fashion.
#Text=These cooking pots are inexpensive,
#Text= and certain foods taste decidedly better if cooked in this way.
#Text=For
#Text= braising, pot roasting, or stewing fruit and other articles which need
#Text=to be cooked slowly under close cover, the application of a moderate,
#Text= even heat produces far better results than if quick heat is applied.
#Text=For such cases the use of earthenware cooking pots is recommended.
#Text=[Illustration]
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= _Time Table for Cooking_
#Text=
#Text= Baking
#Text=
#Text= Beef, loin or ribs, rare, per lb.          8 to 10 minutes
#Text= Beef, loin or ribs, well done, per lb.    12 to 16 minutes
#Text= Beef, ribs, rolled, rare                  12 to 15 minutes
#Text= Beef, ribs, rolled, well done             15 to 18 minutes
#Text= Beef, fillet, rare                        20 to 30 minutes
#Text= Beef, fillet, well done                         60 minutes
#Text= Mutton, leg, rare, per lb.                      10 minutes
#Text=Cheese Fingers
#Text= Vanilla Souffle
#Text= Coffee_
#Text=
#Text= _*Jugged Hare_--1 hare, 1 cup Crisco, 1-1/2 pounds gravy beef, 1
#Text= onion, 1 lemon, 6 cloves, 1 cup port wine, few forcemeat balls, salt,
#Text= red pepper and pepper to taste.
#Text=Skin, paunch and wash hare, cut it into pieces, dredge with flour, and
#Text= fry in hot Crisco.
#Text=Have ready 1-1/2 pints gravy, made from beef, and
#Text= thickened with flour.
#Text=Put this into jar; add pieces of fried hare,
#Text= onion stuck with cloves, lemon peeled and sliced, and seasonings;
#Text= cover jar tightly, put into saucepan of boiling water, and let it stew
#Text= until hare is quite tender, taking care to keep the water boiling.
#Text=When nearly ready pour in wine, add forcemeat balls, and allow to cook
#Text= 10 minutes.
#Text=Serve with red currant jelly.
#Text=For forcemeat balls, mix together in basin, 2 tablespoons Crisco,4
#Text= tablespoons crumbs, 1 tablespoon chopped parsley, 1/4 teaspoon poultry
#Text= seasoning, 1/2 teaspoon grated lemon rind, seasoning of salt, pepper,
#Text=*Stewed Tomatoes
#Text= Cold Slaw
#Text= Cheese Wafers
#Text= Cocoanut Pudding
#Text= Coffee_
#Text=
#Text= _*Stewed Tomatoes_--1 can tomatoes, 2 tablespoons Crisco, 1 cup
#Text= breadcrumbs, seasoning salt, pepper and paprika.
#Text=Empty tomatoes into double boiler, add breadcrumbs, salt, pepper, and
#Text= paprika, and cook slowly for 1/2 an hour, stirring from time to
#Text= time.
#Text=Just before serving add Crisco and stir till melted.
#Text=While the
#Text= tomatoes will be ready with 1/2 hour  '  s cooking, they are improved by
#Text= cooking 1 hour, and are better still if warmed again after cooling.

#Text= _*Beef Steak Pudding_--Line a Criscoed basin with plain pastry.
#Text=Mix
#Text= together on a plate 1 tablespoon flour, 1 teaspoon salt, and 1/2
#Text= teaspoon pepper for seasoning.
#Text=Cut 1 pound lean beef in thin slices,
#Text= dip them in the seasoning, and place them lightly in the basin; split
#Text= 1 sheep  '  s kidney, skin and cut in thin slices; dip them also in the
#Text= seasoning, and put them in basin, and pour over 1 cup of water for
#Text= gravy.
#Text=Wet the edges of the paste on basin; roll out a piece of paste
#Text=Cheese Relish
#Text= *Boston Pudding
#Text= Coffee_
#Text=
#Text= _*Boston Pudding_--Cut 1 loaf bread into thin slices and spread with
#Text= Crisco.
#Text=Crisco baking dish, put into it layer bread, sprinkle over
#Text= 1 tablespoon each cinnamon, cloves, ginger, and nutmeg, then a layer
#Text= seeded raisins, and so on till dish is full.
#Text=Pour over 1 quart milk
#Text= sweetened to taste, with 3 well beaten eggs, allow to soak 4 hours,
#Text= then add 2 cups more milk sweetened to taste.
#Text=Cover dish and bake in
#Text= moderate oven 3 hours.
#Text=Serve with wine sauce.
#Text=December 31
#Text=
#Text= _Codfish, Delmonico Style
#Text= Roasted Leg of Lamb
#Text= *Chestnut Boulettes
#Text= Baked Potato Strips
#Text=Watercress and Green Pepper Salad
#Text= Cherry and Almond Parfait
#Text= Lady Fingers
#Text= Coffee_
#Text=
#Text= _*Chestnut Boulettes_--Mix together in a basin 1 cup mashed chestnuts,
#Text= which have been peeled after cooking in boiling salted water, beat
#Text= into this 1 tablespoon whipped cream, 1/2 tablespoon Crisco, 1/4
#Text= teaspoon salt, 2 egg yolks, 1 tablespoon sugar, 1 teaspoon sherry
#Text= wine.
#Text=Cool and fold in beaten egg whites, form into small balls, dip
#Text= in beaten egg, toss in crumbs and fry in hot Crisco.
#Text=Drain and serve.
#Text=[Illustration]
